channel.title: [C++] Name reformatter

item.title: [C++] Name reformatter
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

It was the same in the introductory courses here too. The purpose goes beyond you understanding though – it helps them verify, to an extent, that the work is yours (and not just copypasta’d from a site found with google).

The last programming assignment I submitted was in C#, done over two days (it was a two part assignment that actually had two months to be completed, as a group). I decided to ditch my partner because a) Our original submission was going to be in Visual Basic (I didn’t know that C# was allowed originally, as I didn’t attend the lectures) and b) He chopped and changed things all the time and it was ridiculous trying to work with that.
So yeah, I churned out the two months of work within two nights, got a credit. Loads of documentation though. Not line by line stupid documentation, but the C# equivalent of java docs.

Would have gotten more, but I couldn’t get it to connect to the MS Access database properly; the credit was effectively for how my solution was designed, implemented, and documented.

Read full topic

@cruel wrote:

You forgot comments on the string assignments:

string last = names[0]; // Assign a string from the start index (0) of the names[] array to the variable 'last' string first = names[1]; // Do the same as above, but this time use index 1 from names[] to get the subsequence item (since 1 comes after 0) in the array, which is a collection of various string. string middle = names[2]; // TODO: Find out what this line does

item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

to be fair, as i have little experience with c++ i found the comments highly useful, I could follow what the program was doing by just looking at the source.

although comments on every line is overkill, it is always better to comment more than less, as long as the comments are relevant of course, wouldn’t you agree?

item.title: [C++] Name reformatter
item.dc:creator: @z z
item.description:
@z wrote:

I was assigned to do a name ‘reformatter’ (I guess you could call it) in my Computer Science class and wanted to post the source code here. We were supposed to use substr and find, but I decided to use strtok and vectors. Would there be a much faster approach to doing this, possibly?

[code]//**************************************************************
// Name split and reformat program
// This program will take an input “last, middle first” and tokenize
// the string, outputting it into the correct format
//**************************************************************
#include
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string.h>
#include

using namespace std;

int main()
{
string input; //input string
char *pointer_char; //pointer for the strtok
vector names; //this is where we will store the names
cout << "Input a name in the format last, first middle: “;
getline(cin,input); //get the input
char *duplicate = strdup(input.c_str()); //duplicate the string into a char so we can utilize strtok functionality
pointer_char = strtok(duplicate,”, “); //tokenize the first split
while(pointer_char != NULL) //while the pointer isn’t null
{
names.push_back(pointer_char); //we push each name into the names vector
pointer_char = strtok(NULL,”, "); //grab the next piece
}
//we assume that the user has input “last, first middle”, so that will be the order of the names array indexing
string last = names[0];
string first = names[1];
string middle = names[2];
cout << first << " " << middle << " " << last << endl;
}[/code]

EDIT: I got 100% for this assignment.

Read full topic
